content.question:
Metformin is a drug used to treat type 2 diabetes by decreasing glucose production in the liver. <math alttext="A M P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>-activated protein kinase <math alttext="A M P K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>AMPK</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a major cellular regulator of glucose metabolism. Metformin activates <math alttext="A M P K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AMPK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in liver cells but cannot cross the plasma membrane. By blocking <math alttext="A M P K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AMPK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> with an inhibitor, researchers found that <math alttext="A M P K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AMPK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> activation is required for metformin to produce an inhibitory effect on glucose production by liver cells.

Which of the following best explains the component that metformin represents in a signal transduction pathway that regulates glucose production in the liver?

choices.label: It is a secondary messenger that amplifies a signal through a cascade reaction.
It is a ligand that activates the signal transduction pathway of the activation of <math alttext="A M P K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AMPK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

It is an allosteric regulator that binds to a crucial section of the <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that makes the enzymes needed for glucose uptake.
It is a competitive inhibitor that binds to glucose and prevents it from entering the cell.

content.answer: It is a ligand that activates the signal transduction pathway of the activation of <math alttext="A M P K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AMPK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
